name: Max Guise

tweet: 13/ Weâ€™re looking for any input about making simple, accessible, self-custodial recovery experiences. Whatâ€™s missing, or unnecessary today? What makes you nervous, and what makes you feel confident and well protected? Let us know at wallet@block.xyz, or here on Twitter.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 12/ Acting as an emergency contact could be as simple as sharing a phone number and using it enter a code the owner shares when reaching out to you for help. How would you design an experience so that less technical users understood its purpose, and their role in protecting you?
name: Max Guise

tweet: 11/ Relying on a circle of people you trust can be a powerful fallback for safer self-custody. A way to allow others to help get you back in control, without having access to the money directly. How would you feel about relying on people close to you to help protect your assets?
name: Max Guise

tweet: 10/ We think weâ€™ll need a reliable way to communicate with customers about recovery events, for safety and ease. What are the right channels (email, SMS, others) for a global audience? How strict should Wallet be in requiring them, to balance privacy vs. safety? Optional ok?
name: Max Guise

tweet: 9/ We think the above tools can be quick to set up, easy to learn to use, and create minimal anxiety to safely maintain. Weâ€™re still exploring details on implementing them, and want to hear from the community about what makes sense and what can be better.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 8/ What about if you lose *both* your App AND Hardware? Call on the trusted friends and family you (optionally) set as emergency contacts to help affirm youâ€™re you, and approve enabling your App and its key on a new device with Social Recovery, before rotating in new Hardware.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 7/ What if you lose the Hardware device you keep in a safe place? Use your App to approve replacing it after waiting through a safety delay, with regular notifications to help make sure itâ€™s really you asking for help.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 6/ What if something happens to the phone you take everywhere? Get a new mobile phone and make a quick approval using your Hardware to restore your App and its key from an encrypted cloud backup.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 5/ With keys distributed across 3 parts of â€˜Walletâ€™ that work together (App, Hardware, and Server), any two can work together to protect or replace the 3rd. So what are some common things that might go wrong, and how are we thinking our Wallet should handle them?
name: Max Guise

tweet: 4/ We think that means excluding complex passwords that people will struggle to memorize (and canâ€™t safely store or reset), identity documents that exclude customers that lack them and compromise privacy of those who do, and even sight sensitive backup material like seed phrases.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 3/ Making that easy enough for a global audience, brand new to self-custody, requires lowering usability barriers wherever we can. When thinking about access and recovery, that means avoiding some common tools we think contribute to an intimidating experience.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 2/ With a multisig design we gain a lot of flexibility for customers to find the right balance of high security and easy access to their money to meet their personal needs, and keep it safe in a single system with confidence and peace of mind.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 1/ Any system that keeps assets safe needs to do two things - (1) let you in, but (2) keep everyone else out. From what weâ€™ve learned about bitcoin holders reluctant to make the leap to self-custody, people are more afraid of making mistakes and running into problems with (1).
name: Max Guise

tweet: One of the most important jobs a bitcoin wallet has is to keep your money safe even when something goes wrong. Weâ€™ve been thinking on how to make forgiving, flexible recovery experiences, and want to hear what you think about them. A post and a ðŸ§µ..  https://t.co/WghEV9gtgb
name: Max Guise

tweet: 3/ Read our post for details on the criteria we use to select the chip - and look out for our â€‹â€‹next post, which will focus on the pros and cons of the specific processor and electrical architecture designs we considered.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 2/ Choosing the right processor is one of the most critical architecture decisions - it impacts how the rest of the electrical system is designed. We define criteria, develop engineering models, and compare designs until we are able to choose the optimal design for our system.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 1/ The main chip - or 'processor' - lives on a printed circuit board that contains the electronics for the hardware component of the wallet, and runs code that signs bitcoin transactions and controls the fingerprint sensor and NFC communication with the phone.
name: Max Guise

tweet: As we build the wallet, we're sharing details of the design along the way. Our newest update covers how we evaluated one of the most critical components in our device, the processor. ðŸ§µ  https://t.co/uXu3K03tO4
name: Max Guise

tweet: 9/ Completing this work will take time, and weâ€™ll include independent experts to verify our approach. We'll share when this work is ready. As always, we're open to feedback along the way - reach us in replies on Twitter or at wallet@block.xyz
name: Max Guise

tweet: 8/ We're assessing fingerprint sensor performance + designing the recovery process customers will use when they lose their wallet. Lots of tradeoffs between protecting against accidental loss and against attackers, while making it easier for a broad audience to own their money.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 7/ When you use the hardware device as a 2nd layer of security, youâ€™ll need to unlock it first. We think most customers will want to prove ownership using their fingerprint. But we realize that doesn't work for everyone, so we're offering PIN as an alternative way to unlock.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 6/ You decide how large of a transaction you want to be able to make using only your mobile app. For any transactions above the limit you set, you'll need to use your hardware device in addition to your mobile app. You'll set the limit in the mobile app.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 5/ For smaller transactions, you only need the key stored in your mobile app - we will provide the second key in response to you when you move money with your mobile app. This lets you keep your hardware device tucked away somewhere safe, reserved for larger transactions.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 4/ You can always move money without interacting with our servers by using your key in the mobile app on your phone + your key in your hardware device. But we donâ€™t expect you to do this for every transaction as you might want more flexibility while still maintaining security.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 3/ Three secret keys protect the money in the wallet. (1) The mobile app and (2) hardware device keys (both controlled by customers), and (3) a key that our servers have. 2 keys are required by the bitcoin network to move money, so only customers, not us, can move money.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 2/ The mobile app allows customers to safely own and manage their bitcoin. The hardware device adds extra security when the customer desires, and acts as a recovery tool when a customer loses their mobile wallet.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 1/ We're building a wallet for people around the world who likely havenâ€™t yet used bitcoin as a savings tool or for its payments capabilities. The wallet is composed of 3 things: a mobile app, a hardware device, and recovery tools.
name: Max Guise

name: Max Guise

tweet: @rr We can disable at a hardware or software level, tbd. Former stronger from a security perspective, but latter is more flexible, can later provide e.g. optional update for customers who want a data connection. It's a spectrum & we have options like shipping with a power-only cable.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 15/ We appreciate all of the input we received when we first shared information about the decision we needed to make - thank you to everyone who contributed. Scrutiny helps us build a better product. What decisions do you want to see next?
name: Max Guise

tweet: 14/ So rechargeable is right for our customers - time to build! Weâ€™ll ensure everyone is set up for success when using our product for the first time and over time. We have more consideration to do here for the global markets we'll serve and localis(z)ation needs for charging.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 13/ Finding the right coin cell replacement can be tough - there are model numbers to interpret and get wrong, the store might not have the right kind in stock, installing them can be tricky, and choosing the wrong one could result in degraded performance or damage the system.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 12/ In addition to AAA, we also looked closely at coin cells. We like that theyâ€™re compact and would allow us to seal the wallet well. But we found weâ€™d need to take significant technical risks in order to compensate for their electrical limits, and we donâ€™t like the experience..
name: Max Guise

tweet: 11/ No decision is perfect. Including a LiPo battery and USB-C connector comes with several limitations. We saw mitigating factors that meant these did not overshadow the customer experience benefits of rechargeable. More detail on this in doc linked at top of thread.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 10/ Additionally, many customers will already have a charging plug and cable from other devices or accessories that require much more frequent charging, like the mobile phone the wallet is intended to pair with.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 9/ With a rechargeable battery, customers will depend on a power source and a USB-C cable when the battery is depleted. We think thatâ€™s OK - customers will only need to charge occasionally, as a result of the battery capacity and the multisignature design referenced above.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 8/ In this setting a rechargeable wallet will work easily, or plugged in if the battery is depleted or degraded. We think this is a better experience than removing corroded AAAâ€™s, scraping the battery terminals, buying batteries, and hoping corrosion didnâ€™t damage the wallet.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 7/ We think many customers will pull their wallet out of a drawer after months or years of non-use, because the 2-of-3 multisignature design we are using will allow customers to safely use only their phone for more frequent transfers.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 6/ Even with a recovery solution, field failures like a broken USB-C connector or a worn out LiPo battery are a hassle for customers to deal with. This is true for any battery choice, so we'll design the hardware to ensure a seamless experience for most people most of the time.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 5/ Estimating and comparing the frequency of hardware failures we might expect for each battery option was less important to us in this decision than evaluating the customer experience during the walletâ€™s lifespan.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 4/ So weâ€™ll provide a recovery solution that keeps customer funds safe even when the wallet hardware is broken or lost. Weâ€™ll detail how that works in this self-custody system in a future post. With this approach to recovery in mind...
name: Max Guise

tweet: 3/ We know that any device has failure modes, and weâ€™re building an inclusive product that lives in context of other devices people use in their lives, not designing the wallet to be operated inside of a volcano. We need to expect that some devices will fail.
name: Max Guise

tweet: 2/ Why a battery at all? We're including features that will ensure the hardware is easy to use for everyone, even when the wallet isnâ€™t in the phone's NFC range and canâ€™t draw power from it. More on what this means in our next newsletter. Now back to which batteryâ€¦
name: Max Guise

tweet: 1/ When evaluating battery options, we anchored our decision on customer experience. In practice, a rechargeable battery option minimizes customer hassle and allows us to design the device to look and feel like the future of money.
name: Max Guise

tweet: We've made a decision! We'll power the wallet with a lithium polymer (LiPo) battery, recharged via USB-C. Weâ€™ll provide flexibility: when the battery's depleted, the wallet will still work plugged in. Why'd we land here? Read on.. ðŸ§µ  https://t.co/7xxVj0if3o
name: Max Guise

name: Max Guise
